status_message: Best known for door-to-door preaching, the Jehovah’s Witnesses now stand accused of a global sexual abuse coverups. W5 investigates the controversial religious sect as it faces international pressure to change the way it handles sex abuse allegations. The controversy surrounds the two witness rule, a biblically-based doctrine that Jehovah’s Witnesses believe in that means any allegation of abuse must be seen by at least two people for it to be punished. We speak to reporter Avery Haines, editor Andre LaPalme and producer Derek Miller about their investigation that airs Saturday on W5.
link_name: W5's Avery Haines and producer Derek Miller

Vesna Vulovic was a 23-year-old Yugoslav Airlines flight attendant when the plane she was aboard exploded in mid-air on Jan. 26, 1972.  

All 27 other passengers and crew died, but Vulovic somehow survived a 10,000-metre plunge to the ground.

A Nanaimo, B.C. woman who says she suffered agonizing pain for 75 days after an operation, has accepted an apology from health officials.

Surgical material was accidentally left inside Marilynne Toole's body following bladder surgery back in April, and was discovered during a trip to Ontario weeks later. 

Her surgeon has apologized for the medical mistake, and Vancouver Island Health Authority says it is "focused on helping medical professionals learn from previous errors."

The baby was at risk of inheriting the mother's DNA for Leigh syndrome, a severe neurological disorder that usually kills within a few years of birth.

The technique involved removing some of the mother's DNA from an egg, and leaving the disease-causing DNA behind. The healthy DNA was slipped into a donor's egg, which was then fertilized. As a result, the baby inherited DNA from both parents and the egg donor.
link_name: World's first baby born with DNA from three people

status_message:
Long time baseball star Alex Rodriguez will play his final major league game next week.

Rodriguez and the club made the announcement before Sunday's home game against Cleveland.

He went on to say he'll stay on with the New York Yankees and become a special adviser and instructor with the team.

"This is a tough day. I love this game and I love this team," he said, often choking up. "And today I'm saying goodbye to both.
A-Rod will play against Tampa Bay at Yankee Stadium on Friday night before ending his career as one of the most prolific and polarizing figures in baseball history.

He was suspended for the entire 2014 season for performance-enhancing drug use.

The 41-year-old designated hitter, a three-time AL MVP and 14-time All-Star, is hitting .204 this season with nine home runs and 29 RBIs in 216 at-bats. His worsening slump finally relegated him to the bench for most of the past month, with Rodriguez getting only one start and seven at-bats in 14 games since July 22 -- he wasn't in the starting lineup Sunday against the Indians.
link_name: Alex Rodriguez to play last major league game next Friday

status_message:
Setsuko Thurlow was barely a teenager when the atomic bomb exploded over Hiroshima.

After seeing a 'bluish-white' flash of light in the window, Thurlow says, before losing consciousness, she "had the sensation of floating up in the air, because all the buildings were collapsing, and mine was collapsing and my body was thrown.”

When she came to, she could hear the 'whispering voices' of her classmates saying, 'God help me, mother help me, I'm here.

'It still rings in my ears.'
link_name: 'Faced with death': Hiroshima survivor fights for nuclear disarmament

status_message:
Happy birthday, Your Majesty.
This official photograph to mark her 90th birthday, shows Queen Elizabeth II with her five great-grandchildren and her two youngest grandchildren in the Green Drawing Room, part of Windsor Castle's semi-State apartments in Windsor, England. 
The children are: James, Viscount Severn, 8 years old, left, and Lady Louise, 12 years old, second left, the children of The Earl and Countess of Wessex; Mia Tindall, holding The Queen's handbag, the two year-old-daughter of Zara and Mike Tindall; Savannah 5 years old, third right, and Isla Phillips, 3 years old, right, daughters of The Queen's eldest grandson Peter Phillips and his wife Autumn; Prince George, 2 years old, second right, and in The Queen's arms and in the tradition of Royal portraiture, the youngest great-grandchild, Princess Charlotte, 11 months old, children of Prince William and Kate Duchess of Cambridge. 
For all things royal, check out www.ctvnews.ca/royals

status_message:
A stunning photo that captured the rare firefall phenomenon, at Yosemite National Park’s Horsetail Falls, has gone viral. 

Photographer Sangeeta Dey Photography explained how she got the shot: “Every year for two weeks in February, the sun sets at a certain angle and illuminates the waterfall in luminescent orange and red, making it look like a fluid fire. I’ve met photographers who said that they have been coming for 11 years only to see this happen 2 or 3 times.

The phenomenon was supposed to happen at around 5:30 in the evening, but I was there at 2 PM to find a spot. I finally settled for a tiny space under a thorny bush. When the fall started glowing, I couldn't believe what I was seeing. For 10 minutes, all of us sat there mesmerized by this spectacle. When it ended, a few of us had tears in our eyes. Some people were clapping. And others were just ecstatic to finally get a chance to see it after trying for years.”
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
This satellite image captured earlier this month shows refugees fleeing violence in Syria clustered at the Rukban tent encampment, one of the last informal crossing points they can use to cross into Jordan.

Yesterday, Jordan disputed a UN report that 12,000 Syrian refugees have amassed in a remote desert area on the kingdom's border, waiting to be let in.  

The UN Refugee Agency says the number of refugees stranded on the border tripled to 12,000 since November because of intensifying fighting in Syria. It has appealed to Jordan to allow them to enter, saying lives are at risk. 

Photo courtesy of Airbus Defence and Space via the Associated Press

South Korean Lee Soon-kyu, right, 85, holds hands with her North Korean husband Oh In Se, 83, on a bus as they bid farewell after the Separated Family Reunion Meeting at Diamond Mountain resort in North Korea, Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. 

Hundreds of elderly Koreans wept and embraced as they parted, perhaps for good, after briefly reuniting for the first time in more than 60 years, after being separated during the turmoil of the 1950-53 Korean War. 

Read more on the bittersweet reunions here: http://ctv.news/GRfvZe

Associated Press photo.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Here’s a shot of Pluto like you’ve never seen before…

NASA unveiled this mosaic of Pluto on Wednesday, representing the global response to its popular “#PlutoTime” social media campaign, which asked earthlings to submit their own snapshots.

The Pluto Time concept was created so that people could experience the approximate sunlight level on Pluto at noon -- generally around dawn or dusk on Earth. Thousands of those submissions have now been assembled into three mosaics of Pluto, Charon, and a combined image of the two. 

The mosaics include not only dim skies on Earth, but famous landmarks, selfies and even family pets. A photo of Clyde Tombaugh, the American who discovered Pluto in 1930, is embedded in this mosaic of hundreds of images shared during the campaign. 

Photo by NASA/JPL
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
NASA's Cassini spacecraft has captured this stunning image of Saturn's icy moon, Enceladus.

NASA scientists expected the north polar region of Enceladus to be heavily cratered, based on low-resolution images from the Voyager mission. But the new, high-resolution Cassini images show a landscape of stark contrasts. "The northern regions are crisscrossed by a spidery network of gossamer-thin cracks that slice through the craters," said Paul Helfenstein, a member of the Cassini imaging team at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York. "These thin cracks are ubiquitous on Enceladus, and now we see that they extend across the northern terrains as well."
link_name: Timeline Photos

In the last week of the federal election campaign, CTV News has invited party leaders to make their closing arguments before voters head to the polls on Oct. 19.

Today, CTV News Anchor Lisa LaFlamme sat down with Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau.

link_name: Sneak peek: Lisa LaFlamme sits down with Liberal Leader Justin...

status_message: Saskatchewan will still have 14 ridings this election -- the same number as in 2011 -- but the province’s riding map has been dramatically redrawn. Regina, the province’s capital city, used to be spread across four rural ridings. But after electoral boundaries were altered in 2012, the city now has two largely urban electoral seats. One of them is Regina-Lewvan  and there’s no incumbent.
link_name: Get to Know a Riding #4 - Regina-Lewvan

status_message: Burnaby North-Seymour, a new urban riding in Metro Vancouver, has been one to watch this election. It was created from portions of North Vancouver, a riding that had previously elected a Conservative MP, and Burnaby-Douglas, an NDP stronghold since 1988. Pipelines have been a key issue in Burnaby North-Seymour.
link_name: Get to Know a Riding #1

status_message:
For the first time in this election campaign, Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau has asked Canadians for a majority government, Conservative Leader Stephen Harper was questioned on why he was campaigning with former Toronto mayor Rob Ford, and NDP Leader Tom Mulcair said that he would immediately decriminalize marijuana if elected.

Full election coverage: http://www.ctvnews.ca/election

status_message: GET TO KNOW A RIDING: The historically Conservative Lethbridge, Alberta shifted from a rural-urban riding to a strictly urban one after the boundaries were redistributed in 2012. After sweeping both Lethbridge seats in the 2015 provincial race, the NDP hopes to win here again at the federal level. NDP Leader Tom Mulcair was the first party leader to stop in Lethbridge during the campaign, announcing a $100-million commitment to mental-health services for young people.
link_name: Get to Know a Riding #4 - Lethbridge

status_message: GET TO KNOW A RIDING: Etobicoke North is also known as Ford Nation. Former mayor Rob Ford and his brother Doug have both represented the  Ward 2 - Etobicoke at City Hall. The ‘Sons of Etobicoke’ welcomed Stephen Harper to the riding on a campaign stop Tuesday. Despite the working class Rexdale base of the riding and the  former mayor’s  personal popularity, the riding has had a Liberal MP for almost 30 years. Can the Liberals hold onto this stronghold?
link_name: Get to Know a Riding #3 - Etobicoke North

Montreal’s re-drawn Ahuntsic-Cartierville riding doesn’t fall short when it comes to interesting candidates. In 2006, under the Bloc Québécois banner, MP Maria Mourani broke the Liberal stronghold in Ahuntsic. She was expelled from the BQ in 2013, and is now running for the NDP. The Conservative candidate was criticized for controversial Facebook comments he made in 2014, and the Liberals are running a former mayoral candidate.  Each candidate has different priorities for the multi-ethnic riding.

When it comes to death, there's traditionally been two forms of eternal rest: going into a coffin or ending up as ashes inside an urn.

But some are embracing a third way -- having their body or brain frozen in liquid nitrogen in the hope of some day being brought back to life, with memories, personality and sense of self intact.

status_message:
Talk about the ultimate photobomb.

This newly-released NASA photo shows the moon, left, and the Earth, top, transiting the sun together, seen from the Solar Dynamics Observatory. 

As NASA’s Solar Dynamics Observatory, or SDO, kept up its constant watch on the sun, its view was photobombed not once, but twice. Just as the moon came into SDO’s field of view on a path to cross the sun, Earth entered the picture, blocking SDO’s view completely. When SDO's view of the sun emerged from Earth’s shadow, the moon was just completing its journey across the sun’s face.

The edge of Earth appears fuzzy because the atmosphere blocks different amounts of light at different altitudes.
link_name: Timeline Photos

Ahmed Mohamed, 14, gives the peace sign as he arrives to his family's home in Irving, Texas.

Encouragement has been pouring in for the 14-year-old Muslim boy in Texas whose homemade electronic clock led to his detention and suspension from school, with U.S. President Barack Obama, Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield among those offering support.
 
As word spread that Ahmed Mohamed, the son of Sudanese immigrants, had been placed in handcuffs after coming to class with the clock that officials at his suburban Dallas school thought resembled a bomb, the teen became a star on social media, with the hashtag .#IStandWithAhmed tweeted more than 1 million times by Wednesday night.

The Russian Hockey Federation was fined Monday over its national team's snubbing of Canada's victory celebrations at the World Hockey Championships.

The sport's governing body, IIHF, said the Russian players deliberately left the ice before ‘O Canada’ was played after the final following a signal from captain Ilya Kovalchuk.

The Russian federation said it accepted the fine, but stuck by its claim that the exit was a case of confusion rather than deliberate disrespect.

status_message:
In what is a very rare occurrence, the Hubble Space Telescope has captured these photos of a triple eclipse on Jupiter.   

Details from NASA: The image on the left shows the Hubble observation at the beginning of the event. On the left is the moon Callisto and on the right, Io. The shadows from Callisto, Io and Europa are strung out from left to right. Europa itself cannot be seen in the image.

The image on the right shows the end of the event, just over 40 minutes later. Europa has entered the frame at lower left with slower-moving Callisto above and to the right of it. Meanwhile Io — which orbits significantly closer to Jupiter and so moves much more quickly - is approaching the eastern limb of the planet. 

The moons of Jupiter have very distinctive colours. The smooth icy surface of Europa is yellow-white, the volcanic sulphur surface of Io is orange and the surface of Callisto, which is one of the oldest and most cratered surfaces known in the Solar System, is a brownish colour.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
2015 is the International Year of Light (IYL) and to recognize the start of IYL, NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory has released images that combine data from telescopes tuned to different wavelengths of light.

NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration uses X-rays to explore the universe so scientists can develop a better understanding of objects likes stars and galaxies that generate temperatures of millions of degrees.

In this image, an expanding shell of debris called SNR 0519-69.0 is left behind after a massive star exploded in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy to the Milky Way. Multimillion degree gas is seen in X-rays from Chandra, in blue. The outer edge of the explosion (red) and stars in the field of view are seen in visible light from the Hubble Space Telescope.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
5 things to know on CTVNews.ca for Monday, Dec. 1, 2014 

1. Canadian kidnapped by ISIS? The Canadian government is looking into a report that Islamic State militants kidnapped Canadian-born Gillian Rosenberg. The Jerusalem Post reported Sunday that the 31-year-old, who was said to have joined Kurdish fighters, had been captured. Kurdish sources say the claims are likely ISIS propaganda. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/ottawa-probing-reports-canadian-israeli-woman-kidnapped-by-isis-1.2126073 

2. Hamilton's heartbreak: The Calgary Stampeders held off the Tiger-Cats to claim the 102nd Grey Cup, after what could have been Hamilton's game-winning punt-return touchdown, had it not been called back due to a penalty. The Stamps were so excited after their win, players accidentally broke the trophy. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/oops-grey-cup-trophy-breaks-as-jubilant-stampeders-celebrate-win-1.2126624 

3. Obama to address racial tensions: Ferguson, MO., where the police shooting of Michael Brown has touched off protests across the continent, will top the agenda when the U.S. President meets with Cabinet on Monday. He will also meet with young civil rights leaders and law enforcement officials.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/obama-to-discuss-ferguson-with-civil-rights-leaders-law-enforcement-1.2126618 

4. Michaelle Jean's new post: Canada's influence may be reaching a little farther, with the appointment of the former governor general to the top job at La Francophonie. Jean is the first woman to hold the post. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/michaelle-jean-named-first-woman-leader-of-la-francophonie-1.2125958 

5. Cyber Monday: After a busy weekend in shopping malls, millions of bargain-hunters are expected to log on and keep buying today. Research firm comScore expects people to spend about USD $2.5 billion this Cyber Monday.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/business/cyber-monday-estimated-2-5-billion-is-on-the-line-1.2126689

1. 'Pierre Poutine' appeals: Former Conservative staffer Michael Sona is expected to appeal his nine-month prison sentence for the role he played in the Guelph robocalls scandal. Sona will also seek bail while he appeals the sentence, his lawyer says.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/michael-sona-to-appeal-sentence-seek-bail-1.2123061

2. CTV News exclusive: A former SNC-Lavalin executive who was appointed to Montreal's port authority by Prime Minister Stephen Harper was allowed to remain on the public payroll for months, despite known links to an illegal fundraising scheme. http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/pm-appointed-gov-t-employee-remained-on-payroll-despite-links-to-illegal-fundraising-1.2123275

3. Snowstorming: A pair of nasty weather systems are bringing early winter woes to Eastern and Western Canada. The Prairies are being hit with heavy, blowing snow and frigid Arctic winds, while the Maritimes face a deluge of wet, soggy snow that threatens to slicken roads and knock out power lines. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/winnipeg-s-homeless-hit-hard-by-winter-weather-1.2121576

4. Heartbeat heard: Eight months after 21-year-old Matthew Heisler died in a house fire, his family has had the chance to hear his heartbeat again. Here's how:
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/it-s-awesome-family-hears-son-s-heartbeat-in-vietnam-war-veteran-1.2122572

5. Black Friday: As shoppers get a jump on their holiday gift lists today, many early-birds are already wrapping their bargains after taking part in what may be the newest U.S. Thanksgiving holiday tradition.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/business/black-friday-comes-early-in-new-u-s-thanksgiving-tradition-1.2123402

status_message:
5 things to know on CTVNews.ca for Monday Aug. 11, 2014

1. Ebola experiments: Medical ethicists are holding a special conference call at the request of the World Health Organization today, to discuss whether it is ethical to use experimental Ebola therapies in this latest outbreak of the disease. It seems the only way to test such treatments is to get them to the scene of a live outbreak, yet new guidelines are needed before conducting such work. There's no word on when the WHO will issue directions.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/who-seeks-expert-advice-on-the-ethics-of-using-experimental-ebola-drugs-1.1952917

2. Iraq assistance: Canada has announced an additional $5 million in humanitarian aid to Iraq. The first $2.25 million will be divided between the International Red Cross, Mercy Corps, and Save the Children Canada, with the remaining funds to be distributed in consultation with Iraqi officials.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/canada-sending-5m-in-humanitarian-aid-to-iraq-1.1953689

3. Animal cruelty case: A British Columbia dog walker who initially reported that six dogs in her care had been stolen now faces charges of animal cruelty and public mischief. After a community-led search effort, the dogs' bodies were found in a ditch in the Fraser Valley. According to Langley RCMP, the dogs died of heat stroke in the back of Emma Paulsens' truck, the same day she reported them stolen.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/b-c-dog-walker-charged-with-animal-cruelty-1.1954078

4. Supermoon snaps: The moon was full and at the closest point in its orbit of Earth on Sunday, prompting photographers around the world to snap some otherworldly shots of our lunar neighbour. http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/look-up-supermoon-photos-from-around-the-world-1.1954087 

5. Ball game record: Blue Jays slugger Jose Bautista ended the Blue Jays' longest game in franchise history with a walk-off single on Sunday, boosting his team over the Detroit Tigers 6-5 in 19 innings.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/bautista-ends-blue-jays-longest-game-in-history-with-walk-off-single-1.1954047
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Calgary police are conducting an aerial search of a rural property near Airdrie, Alta. as an investigation continues into the disappearance of Nathan O'Brien and his grandparents, Alvin and Kathryn Liknes. http://ow.ly/zm8dK
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
5 things to know on CTVNews.ca for Friday July 18, 2014

1. MH17 investigation: In a statement that could have profound implications for the integrity of the plane crash investigation, separatist rebels who control the area where the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was brought down said they had recovered most of its black boxes and were considering what to do with them. The Boeing 777 crashed in southeastern Ukraine Thursday, killing all 298 people on board.  Airline officials have confirmed that at least one Canadian was on flight bound for Kuala Lumpur from Amsterdam.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/ukraine-rebels-claim-to-have-found-most-of-the-crashed-plane-s-black-boxes-1.1919637

2. Ground offensive: Israeli troops pushed deeper into Gaza on Friday to destroy rocket launching sites and tunnels, firing volleys of tank shells and clashing with Palestinian fighters in a high-stakes ground offensive meant to weaken Hamas. Explaining Israel's first major ground offensive in Gaza in more than five years, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said, "We chose to begin this operation after the other options were exhausted and with the understanding that without the operation the price we will pay can be very high."
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/over-20-palestinians-israeli-soldier-killed-in-gaza-ground-offensive-1.1919635

3. Volunteers called off: The bodies of five-year-old Nathan O'Brien and his grandparents Alvin and Kathy Liknes have not been found, but Calgary police say they "do not require assistance from the public in relation to searching public property, however we appreciate the outpouring of community support." Investigators continue to ask private landowners and businesses to check their rural property for anything suspicious.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/volunteer-search-for-missing-calgary-family-called-off-following-police-request-1.1918099

4. Duffy charged: Suspended senator Mike Duffy faces 31 charges in relation to alleged misspending on living and travel expenses, as well as allegedly fraudulent contracts. In total, Mounties say the charges -- which include fraud, breach of trust and bribery of a judicial official – cover expenses of more than $200,000. Get caught up with this look at the key players in the  expense scandal: http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/mike-duffy-key-issues

5. Captain (African-)America: Marvel superhero Sam "The Falcon" Wilson will take the helm as the Avenger in an upcoming installment of the comic book series. The change will arrive this November in "All-New Captain America" No.1. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/african-american-character-will-take-over-as-captain-america-1.1919067
link_name: Timeline Photos

Jose Bautista, of the Toronto Blue Jays, hits during the MLB All-Star Game Home Run Derby.

Oakland Athletics' Yoenis Cespedes repeated as the derby champ: http://ow.ly/zb0yj
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
5 things to know on CTVNews.ca for Tuesday July 15, 2014

1. Amber Alert ends: A suspect is expected to be formally charged with murder after police announced they now believe a missing five-year-old Calgary boy and his grandparents are dead. The bodies of Nathan O'Brien and his grandparents, Kathryn and Alvin Liknes have not been found, but police say they have enough evidence to support the murder charges. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/man-to-face-murder-charges-in-case-of-missing-calgary-boy-grandparents-bodies-not-found-1.1913168

2. Mideast cease-fire: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has warned Hamas that Israel will intensify its campaign of airstrikes against Gaza militants if an Egyptian-proposed cease-fire does not take hold as agreed.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/netanyahu-says-israel-will-intensify-gaza-campaign-if-hamas-rejects-cease-fire-1.1914135

3. AFN meeting: The Assembly of First Nations will begin its annual general assembly in Halifax Tuesday. Discussing the appointment of a new national chief will be one of the first items on the agenda. The AFN has been without a national leader since Shawn Atleo resigned in May, amid controversy over the federal government's proposed changes to aboriginal education. 

4. Signs of Alzheimer's: New research suggests that smell and eye tests could trigger early warning signs for Alzheimer's disease. Two studies showed a link between a weakened sense of smell and loss of brain cell function, while two others showed researchers were able to identify people with Alzheimer's based on levels of a certain molecule found in the eye. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/smell-eye-tests-could-be-early-warnings-for-alzheimer-s-risk-1.1914060

5. Polaris potential: The 10-album short list for the Polaris Music Prize will be announced Tuesday in Toronto. The long list of nominees includes Arcade Fire's Reflektor and Drake’s Nothing Was The Same. The awards gala will be held on Sept. 22. 
http://polarismusicprize.ca/2014-nominees/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
5 things to know on CTVNews.ca for Monday, July 14, 2014

1. World Cup wraps: Germany claimed its fourth World Cup title Sunday with a 1-0 victory over Argentina, after an extra-time goal in the 113th minute of the match. The winning goal was scored by 22-year-old Mario Goetze – who wasn't yet born when West Germany claimed its last World Cup title in 1990. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/world-cup-late-goal-lifts-germany-to-1-0-win-over-argentina-1.1912101

2. Wildfires spread: It's scorching in British Columbia. And as firefighters struggle to contain dozens of wildfires, the hot and dry conditions aren't expected to ease anytime soon, stoking concerns they could spread. Environment Canada forecasts temperatures in the coming days will reach 40 C in some parts of the province – with little to no rain. http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/scorching-temperatures-and-little-rain-fuelling-dozens-of-wildfires-in-b-c-1.1912384  

3. Mideast conflict: In its seventh day of airstrikes on targets in Gaza, the Israeli military says it has shot down an unmanned drone aircraft for the first time since the campaign began. Hamas claimed it launched several drones Monday at Israel, without immediately providing details on their missions.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/israel-downs-drone-along-southern-coast-as-gaza-conflict-enters-7th-day-1.1912543

4. Demolishing history: A government building in Ottawa was reduced to rubble in mere seconds over the weekend, brought down by 400 kilograms of dynamite during a controlled demolition. The 11-storey Sir John Carling building was erected in 1967 on the city’s Experimental Farm. It had served as the headquarters for Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, but was vacant in recent years.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/historic-ottawa-building-reduced-to-rubble-in-seconds-1.1911817 

5. Ontario budget, Take 2: Ontario's Liberal government is set to present a 'do-over' budget at Queen's Park today, just two months after the same document triggered a provincial election. Kathleen Wynne's newly-elected majority government is not expected to change a thing in its $130-billion fiscal plan.

2. Ring recovered: Olympic curling champion Brad Jacobs is breathing a sigh of relief after Mounties recovered his stolen championship ring from the 2014 Sochi Games. http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/stolen-curler-s-2014-olympic-ring-recovered-by-police-1.1888711

3. MacKay uproar: NDP Leader Tom Mulcair is calling on Prime Minister Stephen Harper to replace Justice Minister Peter MacKay in the wake of a sexism scandal. MacKay's recent troubles began when he reportedly said that women aren't interested in becoming judges. In an open letter published Thursday, MacKay's wife defended her husband. According to Nazanin Afshin-Jam MacKay says he is being "savaged by accusers, political opponents and press."
http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/mulcair-calls-for-mackay-to-resign-over-emails-1.1888123

Will this be the world's most expensive stamp?

The British Guiana One-Cent Black on Magenta stamp is held up at of Sotheby's auction house. The sole surviving one-cent of the entire 1856 issue was rediscovered by a 12-year-old Scottish boy living in South America in 1873. 1. Melanoma on the rise: According to the latest Canadian Cancer Statistics report estimates, 6,500 new cases of melanoma and 76,100 cases of non-melanoma skin cancers will be diagnosed in Canada this year, and 1,490 Canadians will die from skin cancer.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/melanoma-among-cancers-still-on-the-rise-report-1.1841369

2. Maternal health summit: Prime Minister Stephen Harper is hosting a three-day international summit on child and maternal health that kicks off in Toronto today. World leaders and health experts will discuss efforts to improve nutrition and immunization in developing countries, but some critics say the PM should focus closer to home, on the issues for newborns and their mothers on First Nations reserves.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/on-eve-of-summit-experts-point-to-aboriginal-infant-mortality-rate-1.1841239

3. Military vows action: Canada's top military commander, Gen. Tom Lawson, has confirmed there will be an independent, external investigation after reports that sexual violence is rampant in the Canadian Armed Forces. MPs at the hearing reacted angrily to news of a three-year delay in reporting such allegations to Parliament.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/lawson-vows-action-on-sexual-assaults-but-military-behind-on-reporting-criminal-stats-1.1840321  

4. Silicon Valley Therapist: According to the designer of the videogame considered by some to be the worst-ever, 'E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial': "I have the greatest range of any designer in history." Here's what Howard Scott Warshaw told an audience in Ottawa Tuesday.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/designer-of-infamously-bad-e-t-video-game-giving-motivational-talks-1.1841281

status_message:
1. 'Bozo eruption': Liberal MP John McKay was secretly recorded saying that he thought Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau had a "bozo eruption" when he declared the party will not welcome anti-abortion candidates. CTV News exclusively obtained the audio recording.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/bozo-eruption-liberal-mp-secretly-recorded-slamming-trudeau-s-abortion-stance-1.1839528

2. Baby abduction: A baby taken from a hospital in Trois-Rivieres was found safe late Monday night. The abduction had prompted an amber alert after a woman dressed as a nurse entered Ville-Marie hospital and took the one-day-old baby wrapped in a blue blanket.
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/amber-alert-quebec-baby-taken-from-trois-rivieres-hospital-1.1839507

3. Canadian connection: George Chen, 19, from Ottawa has been identified as one of the victims of the mass murder at the University of California at Santa Barbara. Calling for tougher gun laws, Chen's mother Kelly Wang said, "We would die a hundred times, a thousand times, but we don't want our kids to get hurt."
http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/the-canadian-connection-to-california-rampage-1.1839678

4. Gunned down in Pakistan: Mehdi Ali Qamar, a Canadian cardiologist, was gunned down in Pakistan in front of his wife and two-year-old son, police said Monday. Qamar's brother said the cardiologist and his family had arrived in Pakistan several days earlier so that he could do volunteer work. 
http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/gunmen-kill-canadian-cardiologist-doing-volunteer-work-in-pakistan-1.1839377

4. Service dogs for veterans: The federal government will formally announce a pilot project today, aiming to provide service dogs for up to 50 veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Veterans Affairs Minister Julian Fantino is expected to announce that his department will provide up to $500,000 for the project. http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/ottawa-to-fund-pilot-project-providing-service-dogs-for-veterans-with-ptsd-1.1839384

status_message:
“Good Night Malaysian three-seven-zero.”

The Malaysian government released a transcript of final recorded conversation between ground control and the cockpit of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 before it went missing, which showed normal exchanges from the cockpit as it requested clearance for takeoff.

"Good Night Malaysian three-seven-zero," were the final words received by ground controllers at Kuala Lumpur's international airport at 1:19 a.m. on March 8. On Monday, the government changed its account of the final voice transmission which it had earlier transcribed as "All right, good night."

To read the full story and transcript: http://ow.ly/vhVoe 

Meanwhile, Malaysia is struggling to defend its credibility in light of the discrepancy: http://ow.ly/vhWdz
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Warning, do not trust everything you read or hear today.

It's April 1, which means every headline and story should be eyed with a different level of scrutiny. Especially anything particularly quirky or jaw-dropping.

Today we have Google for fast fact checking, so even the most elaborate hoaxes can be quickly debunked. But in the days before everyone was wired -- and perhaps a little less savvy about preparing for the annual onslaught of April Fools' Day pranks -- some of the fake stories were a little tougher to immediately discredit, which let some real doozies spread. http://ow.ly/vhsnp

The Canadian couple could take the red-eye from Kuala Lumpur back to Beijing as the kids were waking that Saturday and they could all have the weekend together.

status_message:
SELFIE WITH LLOYD AND LISA

When people find out I work at CTV National News, I’m usually peppered with the same questions. 

“What’s Lloyd like?”
“What’s Lisa like?”

My answer is fairly boring -- the Lloyd and Lisa you see on TV are pretty much the same as the Lloyd and Lisa you see in everyday life. They’re smart and funny -- just the kind of people you’d want to hang out with. This afternoon, Lloyd took a few minutes after his duties with W5 to visit the National newsroom, which he still does on occasion. Couldn’t resist snapping a selfie with him and Lisa and of course, everyone in the newsroom wanted in on the action. You can pick your friends, but you can’t pick your co-workers -- unless you’re the boss -- but isn’t it nice when they can be both? 

My friends and I are busy crafting tonight’s newscast. We have a lot of great stories on the go, including an EXCLUSIVE from Laurie Graham on what’s undoubtedly a setback in Canada-Russian relations.

See you at 11. 

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer

A female WestJet pilot says she was in “shock” after a passenger left behind a note following a weekend flight to say that the cockpit is “no place for a woman.”

status_message:
1. Tired of waking up to another cold day? You're not alone. Meteorologists have confirmed that this winter tops a "misery index" released by the U.S. Weather Services. The index looks at temperatures and snowfall to determine how severe this winter is compared to others. The result: 2014 is one of the most miserable winters on record. Here are the chilly details.

2. The Turmoil in Ukraine continues as the pro-Western government in Kyiv pledges to prevent any national breakup. Early Friday morning dozens of armed men in military uniforms seized an airport in the capital of Ukraine's strategic Crimea region. The events in the Crimea region have heightened tensions with neighbouring Russia.

3. A California senator is asking the U.S. Centres for Disease control to initiate an investigation in a polio-like illness that has caused paralysis in about 20 children in the state. Sen. Barbara Boxer said "we need answers" in her letter to the CDC. So far, doctors haven't identified any common causes to suggest the cases are linked.

4. The Aga Khan, spiritual leader of the world’s 15 million Shia Ismaili Muslims, brought a message of inclusiveness and “equality through pluralism” to the House of Commons. But the New Democrats and Liberals accused the Conservatives of not listening, after the prime minister chose not to invite them to an event honouring the Aga Khan in Toronto today.

5. How good are you at making paper airplanes? Today, teams will try to prove their aeronautical supremacy using everyday office stationary at the 3rd Annual BCITSA Wright Bros Flying Extravaganza Airplane Throwing Contest -- wow, that’s a long name.
Links to these stories:

status_message:
In case you weren't aware, CTV and the non-profit Journalists for Human Rights have teamed up to help journalists tell stories in some of the most challenging places in the world. 

CTV's Ethan Faber is now in Sierra Leone, which is emerging from the darkness of a 10-year civil war. A link to his blog where you can see the work he's doing: http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/ctv-news-in-africa

On Feb. 11, he appeared on the Sierra Leone Broadcasting Corporation show "Good Morning Sierra Leone" to talk about the role of journalism in a democratic society.  In his words, it’s an idea many people still can’t seem to grasp even here in Canada. Here’s the clip:

New guidelines for defining autism spectrum disorders may reduce the number of diagnoses by almost one-third, according to new research from Columbia University.

A review of relevant literature and data, published in the Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders, raises questions about the future of children who have developmental delays, but no longer meet criteria for an autism diagnosis.

DSM, the so-called “bible of psychiatry,” is widely used by experts in both U.S. and Canada to diagnose and classify mental health disorders. http://ow.ly/u1Gso

The proportion of divorced or separated seniors who are 65 and older has tripled in the last three decades, according to the latest Statistics Canada figures.

In 1981, only four per cent of seniors 65 and older were divorced or separated. By 2011, that number had risen to 12 per cent.

However, the majority of those seniors ended up finding another partner, whether they got married again or moved in with a common-law spouse.

Do the findings surprise you?  http://ow.ly/tWiyf

status_message:
Where were you when the Canadian women’s hockey team won their gold medal game in overtime against the Americans? 

Three minutes and 26 seconds. That’s how much time was left in regulation time when the Canadian women’s hockey team began their improbable comeback against their American rivals. The U.S. was up 2-0 and it seemed Canada’s prospects for gold were sliding away. But then, with just 3:26 left to go, the Canadians scored their first goal. Then another. And suddenly, it was tied and the women were off to sudden-death overtime. Not for the faint of heart, if you’re a hockey fan.  By now, you probably know what happened next. The stuff of Olympic legend. Marie-Philip Poulin, who scored in the dying seconds of regulation to tie the game, scored again in overtime. Canada’s golden comeback was complete. A lot of us were watching in the newsroom and hollered, shrieked and jumped when Poulin scored. Where were you when she scored the golden goal? 

By the way, at least the Americans can take (cold) comfort in their stinging defeat knowing they did more to stall workplace productivity in Canada than anything else in recent memory. 

Peter Akman will have the play-by-play tonight of how Canadian women ruled the ice today in Sochi. 

See you at 11. 

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
KYIV ON FIRE, PUTIN FEELS THE BURN 

Ukraine’s capital looks like it’s engulfed in flames tonight. The riot squad moved in on protesters today in Independence Square. But behind the wall of fire, covert politics are at play. Russia is blaming the West for the escalation of violence, even though it’s Moscow’s influence over Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych that protesters find so objectionable. In the days and weeks leading up to the Sochi Olympics, there were grumblings Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying hard to keep the simmering tensions in Kyiv under wraps, at least until the Games were over. So much for that plan. We have two reports tonight on the crisis in Ukraine. Ben O’Hara Byrne will take us through what’s been a deadly day. Laurie Graham will have world reaction. 

See you at 11. 

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

When Prime Minister Stephen Harper meets with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto in Mexico City today ahead of the “Three Amigos” summit, temperatures are forecast to hit a comfortable 25 degrees Celsius. But strained relations between the countries could cast its own chill. 

 “The Mexicans are mad at us in Canada; we’re mad at the Americans; and the Americans seem to have had in up to here with both of us. It’s hard to see anything positive coming out of the summit," says Carlo Dade, director of the Centre for Trade and Investment Policy at the Canada West Foundation who specializes in Canada-Latin American relations.

status_message:
A CTV News exclusive tonight: One of Canada’s most high-profile military leaders claimed more than $72,000 in expenses, including real estate fees, for a move from his Ottawa home to another residence in the city after he retired, CTV News has learned.
Documents obtained by CTV News show retired general Andrew Leslie, who once led Canada’s mission in Afghanistan, claimed the expenses for a move in 2012.
Leslie retired from the military in 2011, but members of the Canadian Forces are entitled to expense one last move after they retire. Critics, however, are calling it a “shocking” amount.
Read the full story here: http://ow.ly/tFpmL

status_message:
Your jaw will drop with this next story. 

A man says he left Mexico in December 2012 for a day of shark fishing and ended up surviving 13 months on fish, birds and turtles before washing ashore on the remote Marshall Islands some 8,800 kilometres away.  

Jose Salvador Alvarenga, 37, washed ashore on the tiny atoll of Ebon in the Pacific Ocean last week before being taken to the capital, Majuro, on Monday. But officials are reacting cautiously to the story. If true, the man's ordeal would rank among the greatest tales ever of survival at sea.

status_message:
Is the Harper government doing enough to help soldiers suffering from PTSD? 

On Christmas Day, Cpl. Leona MacEachern drove straight into a transport truck and died. This was no accident. The 22-year military veteran had been suffering from PTSD and hers was the eighth military suicide linked to the disorder in just two months. Just days after her death, her husband received a letter from Veterans Affairs, offering condolences, but also demanding money from her estate -- a slap in the face, as Cpl. MacEachern’s family was still coming to grips with the magnitude of their loss. Our Richard Madan has the exclusive details tonight on why the government was demanding its due.  

See you at 11. 

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Today is Bell Let's Talk day.

It's estimated 1 in 5 Canadians experience mental illness at some point in their lives, yet only a third of those affected get the help they need. Today, Bell Canada, the company that owns CTV, is donating 5 cents to mental health initiatives for every text, mobile and long distance call as well as every Facebook share using the 'Bell Let’s Talk Image' and every tweet using the #BellLetsTalk hashtag. 

Today, we're doing our part to engage in the national conversation around mental health, beginning with those two simple words: Let's talk. 

How has mental illness impacted your family? 

Find out more and join the conversation: http://ow.ly/t1zQp
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
How has mental illness impacted your family? 

It’s estimated 1 in 5 Canadians experience mental illness at some point in their lives, yet only a third of those affected get the help they need. Tomorrow, Bell, the company that owns CTV, is donating 5 cents to mental health initiatives for every text, mobile and long distance call as well as every Facebook share using the ‘Bell Let’s Talk Image’ and every tweet using the #BellLetsTalk hashtag. But tonight, we’re doing our part to engage in the national conversation around mental health, beginning with those two simple words: Let’s talk. It’s conversation worth having in every Canadian household, even in Rideau Hall, where our Chief Anchor Lisa LaFlamme sat down with His Excellency David Johnston, Canada’s Governor General and his wife, Her Excellency Sharon Johnston. They spoke in candid terms about a difficult time in their lives when mental illness impacted their family. How has mental illness impacted yours?  

See you at 11.  

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Health officials have confirmed Canada’s first human case of #H5N1, or avian flu, after an Albertan died from the virus late last week. http://ow.ly/soKW4 

The individual fell ill on their way back from a trip to China in late December, but officials say there is no evidence that the avian flu had spread to others.

Since 2003, there have been 648 lab-confirmed human cases of H5N1 flu reported in 15 countries. Of those, 384 resulted in death.

status_message:
Can Team Canada bring home the gold at the Sochi Games?

Today we finally learned who will be playing for Canada’s men’s hockey team at the Olympics in Russia next month. It’s a star-studded line-up led by Sidney Crosby, but already the debate has begun as to whether the right players have been selected to defend the gold won in Vancouver.

CTV’s Peter Akman will have a report and TSN’s James Duthie will join Chief Anchor Lisa LaFlamme to discuss the picks. That’s tonight on CTV National News. 

Hope you’ll join us,

Allan Black
Associate Producer

status_message:
Is Rob Ford a victim of a zealous city council? 

He is the most controversial mayor in Toronto’s history. That’s saying something in a city where Mel Lastman was mayor. Remember him? Lastman once joked, just before a diplomatic visit to Kenya, that he was worried he’d be boiled in a pot by African natives. At times today, Toronto City Council resembled a WWE event. Hulk Hogan was nowhere in sight, but one councillor did end up with a fat lip. She was accidently mowed down by an enraged Ford, who was trying to confront a heckler in the audience. Despite all the histrionics of the day -- there was a sobering result. Councillors voted overwhelmingly to strip the mayor of more of his powers. Doug Ford called it a coup d'état. Rob Ford compared it to Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait -- with Ford being Kuwait in this scenario. What do you think? Did Mayor Ford deserve to be neutered today by City Hall or was that an overreach by zealous councillors? CTV’s Peter Akman will have the complete story tonight. 
 
See you at 11. 
 
Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: In this natural colour mosaic image provided by NASA shows Saturn eclipsing the Sun taken by the Cassini spacecraft. With both Cassini's wide-angle and narrow-angle cameras aimed at Saturn, Cassini was able to capture 323 images in just over four hours. This final mosaic uses 141 of those wide-angle images. This image spans about 651,591 kilometers across. (NASA/JPL-Caltech/SSI)

status_message:
What does Remembrance Day mean to you? 

Tonight, our chief anchor, Lisa LaFlamme interviewed the Silver Cross Mother for 2013, Niki Psiharis. She lost her youngest son, Sgt. Chris Karigiannis in 2007, when an improvised explosive device struck his vehicle, west of Kandahar, Afghanistan. He was less than two months from his scheduled return home. For Mrs. Psiharis, this year's Remembrance Day is about honouring her son and representing all mothers of Canada's fallen soldiers. 

Watch her emotional conversation with Lisa LaFlamme on CTV's special coverage of the National Remembrance Day ceremony from Ottawa tomorrow,  presented commercial-free beginning at 10:30am EASTERN. 

In the meantime, feel free to share in the comments section what November 11th means to you.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
On CTV National News, we try to tell stories that enlighten and inform, but there are also those stories that spark much discussion and anger in our comments section. 

Last month, our Ottawa Bureau Chief Robert Fife told us about 1,500 veterans of the Second World War, forced to wait for their Bomber Command honours, simply because the government wanted to hand out the medals in a series of photo-ops with the Veterans Affairs Minister. 
The minister's office reversed course as soon as we started asking questions. 

Last night, Robert Fife had another exclusive, this time, involving a military widow who felt betrayed by the federal government. Her husband died of a heart attack after two previous heart attacks were misdiagnosed by military doctors. 

After accepting at least some blame for her husband's death, one cabinet shuffle later, the government seemingly reversed its own decision. Today, there's been another apparent reversal to the reversal. We'll have an update to the widow's story tonight at 11, but in the meantime, Mercedes Stephenson has been dogging this story for months. You can read her online report here: http://ow.ly/psXhu 

Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
It's still early, but today we're looking at the new population figures, just released this morning. There are now more than 35 million people living in Canada. That overall figure is just part of the story. Some provinces are getting more crowded than others. Ask any television reporter and they'll tell you, stories centred around statistics are always harder to tell. After all, in the TV business, we deal mostly in pictures and words. But these numbers give a snapshot of who we are as Canadians and where we live, so we believe they're important to highlight. Todd Battis has pulled out his calculator and will break down the math for us tonight. Watch his story at 11. 
In the meantime, we want to know: Which province do you live in, and what brought you there?
Rosa Hwang
Senior Broadcast Producer
http://ow.ly/i/3fYbd

status_message: Abandon ship! A Greek air force helicopter flies over a half sunken 60-metre French-flagged yacht sinking off the coast of the Aegean island of Skyros, Greece. The captain said the yacht was taking on water and he had ordered the ship to be abandoned. All eight people on board were rescued. (Greek Navy)

status_message: Giant tuna: Kiyoshi Kimura, president of Kiyomura Co., left, cuts a bluefin tuna in front of his Sushi Zanmai restaurant near Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo Thursday, Jan. 5, 2012. The bluefin tuna caught off northeastern Japan fetched a record 56.49 million yen, or about $747,000 in the first auction of the year at the fish market. The tuna was caught off Oma in Aomori prefecture and just north of the coast that was battered by the March 11 tsunami. (AP / Shizuo Kambayashi)

status_message: Lisa LaFlamme's column today: "The dizzying pace of the daily news cycle online and on TV is only going to accelerate. I see this as good news because 140 characters does not a news story make. It means that at the end of the day, more and more people will NEED what we do best. Context, credibility and basic reporting have never been more important than they are today" ... click to read more, add your comments
